title: South Korea plans to test FLYING CARS as soon as 2025
text:
South Korea has announced plans to invest 1.7 trillion won (£1.1 billion) in self-driving car technology from 2021–2027 alongside aiming to get flying cars airborne by 2025.

Alongside this, the Hyundai Motor Group has revealed its intent to invest 41 trillion won (£27.4 billion / $34.7 billion) in future automotive technology by the year 2025.

The move in parts represents the South Korean automotive-maker's desire to catch up with the rest of the pack in the self-driving car race.

Funding will also be allocated to developing electric cars and connected vehicles — those designed with their own internet access and often wireless network.

The plans come after Hyundai and its affiliates revealed an investment of £1.3 billion ($1.6 billion) towards a joint venture with US-based self-driving tech firm Aptiv.

Hyundai's plans also received a boost from the South Korean government, which has announced that intends to spend 1.7 trillion won (£1.1 billion/$1.4 billion) between 2021–2027 in order to support the uptake of self-driving vehicle technology.

The government expects Hyundai to launch a nationwide service of fully autonomous cars to fleet customers in 2024 and the general public by 2027.

This push is part of a blueprint for future cars announced by President Moon Jae-in during an event at Hyundai Motor's research centre near Seoul.

The government said that it was conducting a feasibility study into its proposed funding boost, which would cover parts, systems and infrastructure.

It added that Korea lags behind in the areas of both self-driving car software and key parts like sensors and chips — all despite the country's advanced, fifth-generation mobile data network.

South Korea also said it would be preparing a regulatory and legal framework to ensure the safety of autonomous cars as they hit the road by the year 2024.

Funding will also be allocated to developing electric cars and connected vehicles — those designed with their own internet access and often wireless network. Pictured, Hyundai executive vice chairman Chung Eui-sun announces plans during an event in Hwaseong

'We will actively transition from combustion-engine cars to future cars,' Industry Minister Sung Yoon-mo said during a media briefing.

In addition, the government also aims to lay the technological and legal groundwork necessary for the demonstration of flying cars by the year 2025.

Hyundai Motor's executive vice chairman Euisun Chung has said that the company is looking to develop flying cars, which could be commercialised ahead of the most advanced self-driving cars.

description: South Korea expects Hyundai to launch a service of autonomous cars to the general public by 2027 - while keeping its eye on the launch of flying cars by 2025.
